old.ruleText: Some casual variants require additional items, such as specially designated cards, nontraditional Magic cards, and dice. old_start See section 9, “Casual Variants.” old_end

new.ruleText: new_start Some cards require coins or traditional dice. new_end Some casual variants require additional items, such as specially designated cards, nontraditional Magic cards, and new_start specialized new_end dice.

The text box of a Class card contains class level bars, each of which is a keyword ability that represents both an activated ability and a static ability. A class level bar includes the activation cost of its activated ability and a level number. Any abilities printed within the same text box section as the class level bar are part of its static ability. See rule 717, “Class Cards.”

“[Cost]: Level N — [Abilities]” means “[Cost]: This Class’s level becomes N. Activate this ability only if this Class is level N–1 and only as a sorcery” and “As long as this Class is level N or greater, it has [abilities].”

old.ruleText: Most Magic games use only traditional Magic cards, which measure approximately 2.5 inches (6.3 cm) by 3.5 inches (8.8 cm). Certain formats also use nontraditional Magic old_start cards, oversized old_end cards old_start that old_end may have different old_start backs. old_end

new.ruleText: Most Magic games use only traditional Magic cards, which measure approximately 2.5 inches (6.3 cm) by 3.5 inches (8.8 cm). new_start Traditional Magic cards are included in players’ decks. new_end Certain formats also use nontraditional Magic new_start cards. Nontraditional Magic new_end cards new_start are not included in players’ decks. They new_end may new_start be used in supplementary decks. Additionally, they may be oversized, new_end have different new_start card backs, or both. new_end

old.ruleText: Nontraditional Magic cards can’t start the game in any zone other than the command zone (see rule 408). If an effect would bring a nontraditional Magic card into the game from outside the game, it doesn’t; that card remains outside the game.

new.ruleText: Nontraditional Magic cards can’t start the game in any zone other than the command zone (see rule 408). If an effect would bring a nontraditional Magic card new_start other than a dungeon card (see rule 309, “Dungeons”) new_end into the game from outside the game, it doesn’t; that card remains outside the game.

old.ruleText: A Shard token is a colorless enchantment token with “{2}, Sacrifice this enchantment: Scry 1, then draw a card.”

new.ruleText: A Shard token is a colorless new_start Shard new_end enchantment token with “{2}, Sacrifice this enchantment: Scry 1, then draw a card.”

old.ruleText: The card types are artifact, conspiracy, creature, enchantment, instant, land, phenomenon, plane, planeswalker, scheme, sorcery, tribal, and vanguard. See section 3, “Card Types.”

new.ruleText: The card types are artifact, conspiracy, creature, new_start dungeon, new_end enchantment, instant, land, phenomenon, plane, planeswalker, scheme, sorcery, tribal, and vanguard. See section 3, “Card Types.”

old.ruleText: Enchantments have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called enchantment types. The enchantment types are Aura (see rule 303.4), Cartouche, Curse, Rune, Saga (see rule 714), Shard, and Shrine.

new.ruleText: Enchantments have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called enchantment types. The enchantment types are Aura (see rule 303.4), Cartouche, new_start Class (see rule 717), new_end Curse, Rune, Saga (see rule 715), Shard, and Shrine.

old.ruleText: Planeswalkers have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called planeswalker types. The planeswalker types are Ajani, Aminatou, Angrath, Arlinn, Ashiok, Basri, Bolas, Calix, Chandra, Dack, Dakkon, Daretti, Davriel, Dihada, Domri, Dovin, Elspeth, Estrid, Freyalise, Garruk, Gideon, Grist, Huatli, Jace, Jaya, Jeska, Karn, Kasmina, Kaya, Kiora, Koth, Liliana, Lukka, Nahiri, Narset, Niko, Nissa, Nixilis, Oko, Ral, Rowan, Saheeli, Samut, Sarkhan, Serra, Sorin, Szat, Tamiyo, Teferi, Teyo, Tezzeret, Tibalt, Tyvar, Ugin, Venser, Vivien, Vraska, Will, Windgrace, Wrenn, Xenagos, Yanggu, and Yanling.

new.ruleText: Planeswalkers have their own unique set of subtypes; these subtypes are called planeswalker types. The planeswalker types are Ajani, Aminatou, Angrath, Arlinn, Ashiok, new_start Bahamut, new_end Basri, Bolas, Calix, Chandra, Dack, Dakkon, Daretti, Davriel, Dihada, Domri, Dovin, new_start Ellywick, new_end Elspeth, Estrid, Freyalise, Garruk, Gideon, Grist, Huatli, Jace, Jaya, Jeska, Karn, Kasmina, Kaya, Kiora, Koth, Liliana, new_start Lolth, new_end Lukka, new_start Mordenkainen, new_end Nahiri, Narset, Niko, Nissa, Nixilis, Oko, Ral, Rowan, Saheeli, Samut, Sarkhan, Serra, Sorin, Szat, Tamiyo, Teferi, Teyo, Tezzeret, Tibalt, Tyvar, Ugin, Venser, Vivien, Vraska, Will, Windgrace, Wrenn, Xenagos, Yanggu, Yanling, and new_start Zariel. new_end

old.ruleText: old_start Phenomenon old_end cards, scheme cards, vanguard cards, and conspiracy cards have no subtypes.

new.ruleText: new_start Dungeon cards, phenomenon new_end cards, scheme cards, vanguard cards, and conspiracy cards have no subtypes.

old.ruleText: Flavor text is italicized text that, like the illustration, adds artistic appeal to the game. It appears below the rules text.

new.ruleText: Flavor text is italicized text that, like the illustration, adds artistic appeal to the game. It new_start usually new_end appears below the rules text.

old.ruleText: An ability word appears in italics at the beginning of some abilities. Ability words are similar to keywords in that they tie together cards that have similar functionality, but they have no special rules meaning and no individual entries in the Comprehensive Rules. The ability words are adamant, addendum, battalion, bloodrush, channel, chroma, cohort, constellation, converge, council’s dilemma, delirium, domain, eminence, enrage, fateful hour, ferocious, formidable, grandeur, hellbent, heroic, imprint, inspired, join forces, kinship, landfall, lieutenant, magecraft, metalcraft, morbid, parley, radiance, raid, rally, revolt, spell mastery, strive, sweep, tempting offer, threshold, undergrowth, and will of the council.

new.ruleText: An ability word appears in italics at the beginning of some abilities. Ability words are similar to keywords in that they tie together cards that have similar functionality, but they have no special rules meaning and no individual entries in the Comprehensive Rules. The ability words are adamant, addendum, battalion, bloodrush, channel, chroma, cohort, constellation, converge, council’s dilemma, delirium, domain, eminence, enrage, fateful hour, ferocious, formidable, grandeur, hellbent, heroic, imprint, inspired, join forces, kinship, landfall, lieutenant, magecraft, metalcraft, morbid, new_start pack tactics, new_end parley, radiance, raid, rally, revolt, spell mastery, strive, sweep, tempting offer, threshold, undergrowth, and will of the council.

Similar to ability words, flavor words appear in italics at the beginning of some abilities. Flavor words provide a flavorful description of abilities, but they have no special rules meaning and are not listed in the Comprehensive Rules. While an ability word ties together several abilities with similar functionality, each flavor word is tailored to the specific ability it appears with.

old.ruleText: The chaos symbol {CHAOS} appears in the text box of each plane card to the left of a triggered ability that triggers whenever {CHAOS} is rolled on the planar die. The symbol itself has no special rules meaning.

new.ruleText: The chaos symbol {CHAOS} appears in the text box of each plane card to the left of a triggered ability that triggers whenever {CHAOS} is rolled on the planar die. The symbol itself has no special rules meaning. new_start See rule 901, “Planechase.” new_end

old.ruleText: old_start An old_end Equipment old_start is old_end cast old_start and enters old_end the battlefield old_start just old_end like old_start any old_end other old_start artifact. An Equipment doesn’t old_end enter the battlefield attached to a creature. The equip keyword ability attaches the Equipment to a creature you control (see rule 702.6, “Equip”). Control of the creature matters only when the equip ability is activated and when it resolves. Spells and other abilities may also attach an Equipment to a creature. If an effect attempts to attach an Equipment to an object that can’t be equipped by it, the Equipment doesn’t move.

new.ruleText: Equipment new_start spells are new_end cast new_start like other artifact spells. Equipment enter new_end the battlefield like other new_start artifacts. They don’t new_end enter the battlefield attached to a creature. The equip keyword ability attaches the Equipment to a creature you control (see rule 702.6, “Equip”). Control of the creature matters only when the equip ability is activated and when it resolves. Spells and other abilities may also attach an Equipment to a creature. If an effect attempts to attach an Equipment to an object that can’t be equipped by it, the Equipment doesn’t move.
Some enchantments have the subtype “Class.” See rule 717 for more information about Class cards.
Dungeon is a card type seen only on nontraditional Magic cards.

Dungeon cards begin outside the game. Dungeon cards aren’t part of a player’s deck or sideboard. They are brought into the game using the venture into the dungeon keyword action. See rule 701.46, “Venture into the Dungeon.”
If a player ventures into the dungeon while they don’t own a dungeon card in the command zone, they choose a dungeon card they own from outside the game and put it into the command zone.
A dungeon card that’s brought into the game is put into the command zone until it leaves the game.
Dungeon cards are not permanents. They can’t be cast. Dungeon cards can’t leave the command zone except as they leave the game.
If an effect other than the venture into the dungeon keyword action would bring a dungeon card into the game from outside the game, it doesn’t; that card remains outside the game.
A player can own only one dungeon card in the command zone at a time, and they can’t bring a dungeon card into the game if a dungeon card they own is in the command zone.
Each dungeon card has a series of rooms connected to one another with arrows. A player uses a venture marker placed on the dungeon card they own to indicate which room they are currently in.
As a player puts a dungeon they own into the command zone, they put their venture marker on the topmost room.
Each room has a name. These names are considered flavor text and do not affect game play.

Each room has a triggered ability called a room ability whose effect is printed on the card. They all have the same trigger condition not printed on the card. The full text of each room ability is “When you move your venture marker into this room, [effect.]” As long as a dungeon card is in the command zone, its abilities may trigger. Each room ability is controlled by the player who owns the dungeon card that is that ability’s source.
The venture into the dungeon keyword action allows players to move their venture marker down the rooms of a dungeon card.

If a player ventures into the dungeon while they own a dungeon card in the command zone and their venture marker isn’t on that dungeon’s bottommost room, they move their venture marker from the room it is in to the next room, following the direction of an arrow pointing away from the room their venture marker is in. If there are multiple arrows pointing away from the room the player’s venture marker is in, they choose one of them to follow.

If a player ventures into the dungeon while they own a dungeon card in the command zone and their venture marker is on that dungeon card’s bottommost room, they remove that dungeon card from the game. They then choose a dungeon card they own from outside the game and put it into the command zone. They put their venture marker on the topmost room.

If a player’s venture marker is on the bottommost room of a dungeon card, and that dungeon card isn’t the source of a room ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, the dungeon card’s owner removes it from the game. (This is a state–based action. See rule 704.)
A player completes a dungeon as that dungeon card is removed from the game.
The owner of a vanguard card is the player who started the game with it in the command zone. The controller of a face–up vanguard card is its owner.
The owner of a scheme card is the player who started the game with it in the command zone. The controller of a face–up scheme card is its owner.

If a non–ongoing scheme card is face up in the command zone, and no triggered abilities of any scheme are on the stack or waiting to be put on the stack, that scheme card is turned face down and put on the bottom of its owner’s scheme deck the next time a player would receive priority. (This is a state–based action. See rule 704.)
The owner of a conspiracy card is the player who put it into the command zone at the start of the game. The controller of a conspiracy card is its owner.

old.ruleText: Some effects bring cards into a game from outside old_start of it. old_end Those cards remain in the game until old_start it ends or old_end their owner leaves the game, whichever comes first.

new.ruleText: Some effects bring cards into a game from outside new_start the game. new_end Those cards remain in the game until new_start the game ends, new_end their owner leaves the game, new_start or a rule or effect removes them from the game, new_end whichever comes first.

old.ruleText: The player pays the total old_start cost old_end in any order. Partial payments are not allowed. Unpayable costs can’t be paid.

new.ruleText: The player pays the total new_start cost. First, they pay all costs that do not involve random elements or moving objects from hidden zones to public zones in any order. Then they pay all remaining costs new_end in any order. Partial payments are not allowed. Unpayable costs can’t be paid.

Some effects refer to a triggered ability of an object. Such effects refer only to triggered abilities the object has, not any delayed triggered abilities (see rule 603.7) that may be created by abilities the object has.

old.ruleText: A old_start replacement effect or a old_end resolving spell or ability may allow or instruct a player to take an action and create a triggered ability that triggers “when [a player] [does or doesn’t]” take that action or “when [something happens] this way.” These reflexive triggered abilities follow the rules for delayed triggered abilities (see rule 603.7), except that they’re checked immediately after being created and trigger based on whether the trigger event or events occurred earlier during the resolution of the spell or ability that created them. If the trigger event or events occur multiple times during that time, the reflexive triggered ability will trigger once for each of those times.

new.ruleText: A resolving spell or ability may allow or instruct a player to take an action and create a triggered ability that triggers “when [a player] [does or doesn’t]” take that action or “when [something happens] this way.” These reflexive triggered abilities follow the rules for delayed triggered abilities (see rule 603.7), except that they’re checked immediately after being created and trigger based on whether the trigger event or events occurred earlier during the resolution of the spell or ability that created them. If the trigger event or events occur multiple times during that time, the reflexive triggered ability will trigger once for each of those times.

old.ruleText: If an ability old_start of an object old_end uses a phrase such as “this [something]” to identify an object, where [something] is a characteristic, it is referring to that particular object, even if it isn’t the appropriate characteristic at the time.

new.ruleText: If an ability uses a phrase such as “this [something]” to identify an object, where [something] is a characteristic, it is referring to that particular object, even if it isn’t the appropriate characteristic at the time.

old.ruleText: Certain spells and abilities can goad a creature. Until the next turn of the controller of that spell or ability, that creature old_start attacks each combat if able and attacks a player other than that player if able. old_end

new.ruleText: Certain spells and abilities can goad a creature. Until the next turn of the controller of that spell or ability, that creature new_start is goaded. new_end

old.ruleText: A old_start static ability may state that a creature “is goaded.” That old_end creature attacks each combat if able and attacks a player other than the controller of the old_start permanent with old_end that old_start static ability old_end if able.

new.ruleText: new_start Goaded is a designation a permanent can have. new_end A new_start goaded new_end creature attacks each combat if able and attacks a player other than the controller of the new_start permanent, spell, or ability new_end that new_start caused it to be goaded new_end if able. new_start Goaded is neither an ability nor part of the permanent’s copiable values. new_end
A creature can be goaded by multiple players. Doing so creates additional combat requirements.

old.ruleText: Once a player has goaded a creature, the same player goading it again has no effect. old_start It old_end doesn’t create additional combat requirements.

new.ruleText: Once a player has goaded a creature, the same player goading it again has no effect. new_start Doing so new_end doesn’t create additional combat requirements.

If a player is instructed to venture into the dungeon while they don’t own a dungeon card in the command zone, they choose a dungeon card they own from outside the game and put it into the command zone. They put their venture marker on the topmost room. See rule 309, “Dungeons.”

If a player is instructed to venture into the dungeon while their venture marker is in any room except the dungeon card’s bottommost room, they choose an adjacent room, following the direction of an arrow pointing away from their current room. If there are multiple arrows pointing away from the room the player’s venture marker is in, they choose one of them to follow. They move their venture marker to that adjacent room.

If a player is instructed to venture into the dungeon while their venture marker is in the bottommost room of a dungeon card, they remove that dungeon card from the game. Doing so causes the player to complete that dungeon (see rule 309.7). They then complete the procedure outlined in rule 701.46a again.

old.ruleText: If old_start a permanent leaves the battlefield old_end before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had lifelink.

new.ruleText: If new_start an object changes zones new_end before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had lifelink.

old.ruleText: If old_start a permanent leaves the battlefield old_end before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had wither.

new.ruleText: If new_start an object changes zones new_end before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had wither.

Some enchantments have the subtype Class and associated abilities that give them a class level. These are not the same as level up abilities and class levels do not interact with level counters. See rule 717, “Class Cards.”

old.ruleText: If old_start a permanent leaves the battlefield old_end before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had infect.

new.ruleText: If new_start an object changes zones new_end before an effect causes it to deal damage, its last known information is used to determine whether it had infect.

If a player’s venture marker is on the bottommost room of a dungeon card, and that dungeon card isn’t the source of a room ability that has triggered but not yet left the stack, the dungeon card’s owner removes it from the game. See rule 309, “Dungeons.”
An effect that instructs a player to roll a die will specify what kind of die to roll and how many of those dice to roll.

Such an effect may refer to an “N–sided die,” “N–sided dice,” or one or more “dN,” where N is a positive integer. In all cases, the die must have N equally–likely outcomes, numbered from 1 to N. For example, a d20 is a twenty–sided die with possible outcomes from 1 to 20.

Players may agree to use an alternate method for rolling a die, including a digital substitute, as long as the method used has the same number of equally–likely outcomes as the die specified in the instruction.

After the roll, the number indicated on the top face of the die before any modifiers is the natural result. The instruction may include modifiers to the roll which add to or subtract from the natural result. Modifiers may also come from other sources. After considering all applicable modifiers, the final number is the result of the die roll.
Some abilities that instruct a player to roll one or more dice include a results table.

The results table appears as a chart with multiple striations. Each striation includes possible results and an effect associated with those results. The possible results indicated could be a single number, a range of numbers with two endpoints in the form “N1–N2,” or a range with a single endpoint in the form “N+.” Each striation of the results chart means “If the result was in this range, [effect].” After a die roll, use the result to determine which effect listed on the results table happens.

An instruction to roll one or more dice, any instructions to modify that roll printed in the same paragraph, any additional instructions based on the result of the roll, and the associated results table are all part of one ability.
Some effects in results charts include the text “Roll again.” This additional roll uses the same kind of and number of dice originally called for, including any applicable modifiers.
Some abilities that instruct a player to roll one or more dice do not include a results table. The text of those abilities will indicate how to use the results of the die rolls.

If a player is instructed to roll two or more dice and ignore the lowest roll, the roll that yielded the lowest result is considered to have never happened. No abilities trigger because of the ignored roll, and no effects apply to that roll. If multiple results are tied for the lowest, the player chooses one of those rolls to be ignored.

In a Planechase game, rolling the planar die will cause any ability that triggers whenever a player rolls one or more dice to trigger. However, any effect that refers to a numerical result of a die roll, including ones that compare the results of that roll to other rolls or to a given number, ignores the rolling of the planar die. See rule 901, “Planechase.”

Some enchantments have the subtype Class and associated abilities that give them a class level. These are not level up abilities and class levels do not interact with level counters. See rule 717, “Class Cards.”
Each Class card has a striated text box containing two class level bars. Its illustration is vertically oriented on the left side of the card, and its type line is along the bottom of the card.

A class level bar is a keyword ability that represents both an activated ability and a static ability. A class level bar includes the activation cost of its activated ability and a level number. Any abilities printed within the same text box section as the class level bar are part of its static ability.

“[Cost]: Level N — [Abilities]” means “[Cost]: This Class’s level becomes N. Activate this ability only if this Class is level N–1 and only as a sorcery” and “As long as this Class is level N or greater, it has [abilities].”
A level is a designation that any permanent can have. A Class retains its level even if it stops being a Class. Levels are not a copiable characteristic.
The phrase “to gain a Class level” means “to activate an ability indicated by a class level bar”
If a rule or effect refers to a permanent’s level and that permanent doesn’t have a level, it is treated as though its level is 1.

Any ability printed on a Class card that isn’t preceded by a class level bar is treated normally. In particular, the Class has the ability printed in its top text box section at all times. That ability may affect the game if it’s a static ability, it may trigger if it’s a triggered ability, and it can be activated if it’s an activated ability.

Some older creature cards, called leveler cards, have level up abilities that add level counters to them. These are not the same as class level abilities. Level counters do not interact with Class cards, and class levels do not interact with leveler cards. See rule 702.87, “Level Up,” and rule 711, “Leveler Cards.”

If there are any triggered abilities that triggered before this process began but haven’t been put onto the stack yet, those abilities cease to exist. They won’t be put onto the stack. This rule does not apply to abilities that trigger during this process (see rule 719.1f).

Exile every object on the stack, including the object that’s resolving. All objects not on the battlefield or in the command zone that aren’t represented by cards will cease to exist the next time state–based actions are checked (see rule 704, “State–Based Actions”).
Check state–based actions. No player gets priority, and no triggered abilities are put onto the stack.

Rolling the planar die will cause any ability that triggers whenever a player rolls one or more dice to trigger. However, any effect that refers to a numerical result of a die roll, including ones that compare the results of that roll to other rolls or to a given number, ignores the rolling of the planar die. See 706, “Rolling a Die.”

old.ruleText: If a player is allowed to bring a card from outside the game into a Commander game, that player can’t bring a card into the game this way if it has the same name as a card that player had in their starting deck, if it has the same name as a card that the player old_start has already brought into old_end the game, or if any color in its color identity isn’t in the color identity of the player’s commander.

new.ruleText: If a player is allowed to bring a card from outside the game into a Commander game, that player can’t bring a card into the game this way if it has the same name as a card that player had in their starting deck, if it has the same name as a card that the player new_start owns in new_end the new_start current new_end game, or if any color in its color identity isn’t in the color identity of the player’s commander.
